These sentences use the "te" form of the verb plus the auxiliary verb "iru", and are similar to the pattern "be doing" in English. We will also considering making sentences in both polite and plain forms. Two main forms to be practised in this lesson can be summarised by the following examples.

japanese.content: 父は新聞を読んでいます
ちちはしんぶんをよんでいます

translated.content: My father is reading the newspaper.

japanese.content: 父は新聞を読んでいる
ちちしはしんぶんよんでいる

translated.content: My father is reading the newspaper.

japanese.content: サリーさんは皿を洗っていますか
サリーさんはさらをあらっていますか
サリーさんは皿を洗っています
サリーさんはさらをあらっています

grammar_points.p: Sentences which express a state or ongoing action are formed by using the "te" form of the verb plus the auxiliary verb "iru". This pattern corresponds closely to the combination of "be" plus a gerund in English. (For example, "I am reading.") Unlike sentences which express existence using only the verb "iru", in this pattern "iru" is used for both people and inanimate objects. The polite form of this pattern is formed by using "imasu", the polite form of "iru".

tr.td: ジョンさんは喫茶店でコーヒーを飲んでいる - "John is drinking coffee in a coffee shop." (plain)
妹は本を読んでいる - "My younger sister is reading a book." (plain)
田中さんは学校でサリーさんを待っています - "Tanaka is waiting for Sally at school." (polite)
兄はサムさんと話しています - "My older brother is talking to Sam." (polite)

grammar_points.p: Adding the question marker "ka" changes the statement into a question.

tr.td: 鈴木さんはテレビを見ていますか - "Is Suzuki watching television?"
田中さんは魚を食べていますか - "Is Tanaka eating fish?"
